text: send a tradeoff and then figure out what you're going to do about it later right that sounds about right for most of us and if you're anything like me when I first started trading back in 2007 I was in high school and I was a super patient young man obviously not the case so the goal of this video is actually to walk you through risk management and options trading specifically what I wish I knew 16 years ago what's up everybody Eric here welcome back to the outliers shout out to the patreon let's get straight into it so what's the purpose of this topic it's kind of straightforward but it's so that you don't end up like this person which I can't really pronounce their name but this is actually from the options subreddit they lost 167,000 then we got this person from Wall Street bets Who's down 98.81 got this person who's essentially asking uh subreddit if they should wheel this thing with 550 bucks we got this person who lost 650,000 on short calls it looks like maybe long calls yeah it looks like long calls who knows at this point then we have another one from Wall Street bets where we are down actually a impressive 101 kind of good for them really overachieving here what I'm highlighting is this is what most people do it is a fact of the trade that most people that get into trading start off half cocked

text: Beyond avoiding this fate for me it was to enable long-term compounding that's what I cared about and I've shared my St a bunch of times I'm not going to bore you with it in this video what I want to draw your attention to are the different ways we can make money in the market so you'll notice that as we go further down on our account draw Downs the larger the return required is in order to get back to break even so in this case if you draw down 40 in order to get back to break even you have to see an appreciation of 66.7 that's not making any money that's getting just back to break even so what I want to draw your attention to specifically are these different portfolios because you notice that portfolio 3 actually has a better return a better average return of 8.6 but notice how the compound annual growth rate is 6.87 compared to portfolio 1 that has a lower average return of 1.2 at 7.4 yet they have a better compound in your growth rate how is that because they're not experiencing as much whipsaw in their return profile so for me this is what I focused on and over the life cycle of my trading I've evolved what my purpose was however what always stuck with me is limiting the draw down on my account and that's actually led to me only posting two negative years and that

text: so for me this is what I focused on and over the life cycle of my trading I've evolved what my purpose was however what always stuck with me is limiting the draw down on my account and that's actually led to me only posting two negative years and that was my first two years of trading in the beginning I was just really risk averse however what I started to realize as I was creating what I call my millionaire road map what I was trying to accomplish I noticed that even by having more conservative Topline returns by limiting my draw Downs I was actually accelerating my compound growth Target and rate massively so that's exactly why this was my purpose you have to Define yours and I encourage you to do that when you think about your approach to managing risk in trading not just options it can't just be I don't want to blow up if it's something so nebulous it doesn't mean anything I would quantify it very specifically I do not want to have a greater than 30 draw down on my total portfolio whatever it is for you that makes sense you have to go through this process because if you just say the easy answer of oh I'm just going to limit draw Downs or oh I just want less portfolio variance yeah it's sounds good but unless you start getting specific with it it's you're just saying things that sound good

text: we're trying to not trade for a year 5 year 10 years 20 years we're trying to trade for a lifetime we're trying to create lifechanging wealth and to sustainably do it over time so thinking about things like our ego the dun and Krueger effect they're massive a couple other things I want to highlight from this list and then you're free to check out whatever you want upfront is the the disposition effect and that's actually from the behavior of individual investors this study here this is the tendency where we like to take winning trades down too fast and let losing trades run this happens for two reasons one from a psychological perspective we like realizing a gain we feel good our ego likes that we're confronted with the outcome that we did a good job we don't like confronting ourselves with the fact that we did something that didn't work well and then this is where we start hoping hoping that it works out typically doesn't the other thing to note about the disposition effect and how it roots in our brains is kind of Primal actually and it's called loss of version and this kind of has Primal rooting where we don't look at the value of a gain or a commensurate loss the same and this happens because once your basic life needs are met the prospect of losing a little bit is problematic because then it can set you below what you need

text: of has Primal rooting where we don't look at the value of a gain or a commensurate loss the same and this happens because once your basic life needs are met the prospect of losing a little bit is problematic because then it can set you below what you need for for basic needs but this also carries over into other markets where you can actually have a better expected return to the outside to the upside versus losing to the downside so what that means is say for example if it's a fair coin flip and you can win one and a half units if it's heads and you lose one unit or one and a quarter units if it's Tails people don't wait those outcomes appropriately whereas that has positive expected return but people become too risk averse and if you offered them the ability to just take a dollar up front even though that system would potentially make them more they wouldn't take that trade so that's loss aversion now a couple other things effort Gap is a big one with respect to trading and this is where Traders feel like because they put in a ton of effort that they deserve something that the market owes them to be right that the you know because they've spent hundreds of hours they should be performing well because of all that effort doesn't matter literally doesn't matter you can spend a lot of time doing this stuff and

text: analysis look at things like net highs and lows moving averages just to get a sense of how the market is trending I'm also going to see how earnings for the last quarter have been see if there's any big economic events coming out or that the market is particularly sensitive to a good example of that right now is the rate environment Market's hyper sensitive to that as of this moment whereas back in 2013 yeah not so much because it wasn't so topical then and also how volatile things are the reason why I look at all of this before I even start thinking about the risk of positions is because this informs how I structure my risk later on so for example if I'm trading earnings plays and the earnings so far has been all over the place that's going to inform what strategies I might use and how I'm going to set those strategies up so this is laying a foundation for further decision then we look at the portfolio so from a portfolio level when I'm first deciding how I conceive of risk I think about Max draw down for the portfolio that's super important and this is where you determine what is the maximum allowable Capital draw down you will accept in your portfolio before you deploy circuit breakers and circuit breakers are literally when you start liquidating positions even if it might not make sense to make sure that you're not missing something

text: that position on your broker is going to require a certain amount of money and that margin requirement in this case is something like 1,000 bucks however if the underlying starts moving against you and let's say it goes goes up one standard deviation your margin requirement is now 1,700 bucks and let's say it goes up two standard deviations now it's 2,600 bucks and if it goes up three standard deviations now it's up 3,900 bucks margin moves so if you're trading using options that's great you're gaining effective leverage and being more Capital efficient however you have to be mindful of how margin will move throughout the life cycle of a position again you can't have goldilock scenario analysis where you're just thinking about things when they go well so for me I would absolutely consider something like a three standard deviation move against me to understand what it might look like it's insanely improbable but they do happen and that's the way that my brain thinks about managing risk so that I don't get caught the other things I'm going to look at in the portfolio are the correlation between products to make sure that I'm not putting on five different positions that really all behave like the same one without knowing it I'm also going to take a look at what days to expirations I have for all my different positions what needs to be managed because of time based reasons am I at risk of

text: let me double check yeah he made over 100 million and this is back in like the 1930s so think about how much money that is then this gentleman over here lost 800 27 million for a bank the point being is you can't get too risk desensitized they're both successful knocked it out of the park some of them for a long time and then they still it up at some point because they develop a perverse relationship with risk you're not out of the woods when you're a successful Trader it takes time and the last thing if you're too risk averse you put on positions too small you take them down too fast you're not going to make any money so think about position sizing typically for me speculative allocation maybe up to 25 vast majority of the time 10 to 15 core allocation very different can go the full portfolio but typically much larger size because of the way that I trade that make it make sense remember draw Downs really hurt you long term don't let it happen take the short-term loss sucks but it lets you start from a better Point going forward establish all of this ahead of time if you have any questions let me know like subscribe share be an outlier see youall later
